bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Daniel Salmon was a member of Cornell University's first class of graduates. He earned his bachelor's degree in veterinary medicine in 1872, and four years later Cornell awarded him the the first DVM degree in the country. Dr. Salmon went on to serve as the founding chief of the US Bureau of Animal Industry and is best known today for identifying the infectious pathogen Salmonella and pioneering the fight against contagious diseases.

chronitem.event: Born in Mount Olive, New Jersey
Received bachelor's degree in veterinary science
Earned first D.V.M. degree in the United States
Named first chief of the Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Animal Industry
Founded National Veterinary College in Washington, D.C.
Mary Thompson Corning, first wife, died
Left Bureau of Animal Industry following meat packing controversy roused by Upton Sinclair's The Jungle
Moved to Uruguay to found a veterinary college in Montevideo
Returned to the United States, managed a hog cholera serum company in Butte, Montana

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Two scrapbooks on the Nebraska Hog Cholera controversy of the late 19th century, and an unpublished manuscript on susceptibility and immunity.

The scrapbooks were compiled by Salmon from 1886-1893, and document the commentary and criticism relating to the Hog Cholera epidemic in Nebraska. Many of the articles and editorials were written by Dr. Frank S. Billings and are highly critical of the response of the Bureau of Animal Industry, as well as Salmon's leadership.
The manuscript is 268 pages long and in Spanish. It was probably sent to Dr. Simon Henry Gage for editing some time during Salmon's time in Uruguay.
Also, an article on Salmon from a Hungarian veterinary magazine.

altformavail.head: Available Copies:
altformavail.p: The scrapbooks are available on microfilm from the Library Annex, Film # N6131

acqinfo.head: PROVENANCE
acqinfo.p: The scrapbooks were originally cataloged in the Flower Veterinary Library. The manuscript was found in the papers of Dr. Grant Sherman Hopkins after his death in 1952, then kept by Dean William Hagan. The manuscript was removed from the Hagan papers in 2004.
